historia.titulo: Where nature and love come together
historia.contenido: According to oral tradition, this waterfall witnessed ancient union rituals between couples seeking to bless their love with the strength of water and nature. It is said that its waters hold the whispers of eternal promises, and that those who approach with a sincere heart can feel the energy of the lovers who once sealed their destiny here.
historia.significadoCultural: To feel the love of the water

leyenda.titulo: The stone that cries on a full moon
leyenda.contenido: The elders say that during full moons, the stone 'weeps' dewdrops that have healing properties. The legend says it was a Mixe princess turned to stone by the gods to protect her people, and her tears are blessings for visitors pure of heart.
leyenda.moral: Sacrifice for the community is eternally remembered

testimonios.persona: Don Felipe, Guardian of the Site
testimonios.testimonio: My grandfather told me that his great-grandfather witnessed the first Spaniards trying to move the stone, but they couldn't. He said the land itself protected it.
Upon studying the engravings, we discovered they coincide with specific astronomical events. The precision is astonishing considering the era.

galeriaHistorica.descripcion: Symbols representing constellations and agricultural cycles
Historical photograph of a traditional ceremony

cronologia.descripcion: Mixe communities establish the site as a ceremonial center
First European record of the site in colonial chronicles
First scientific study by Mexican anthropologists

historia.contenido: This centenary ahuehuete was planted in 1845 by the first municipal president of San Juan Tahitic. Crucial decisions were made under its shade during the Mexican Revolution, and it served as a meeting point for revolutionaries in the region.
historia.significadoCultural: Symbol of resistance and community unity

leyenda.titulo: The tree that listens to secrets
leyenda.contenido: Tradition says that if you whisper a secret to the tree and it moves its leaves, your wish will come true. Many couples have come here to promise eternal love, and the elders assure that the tree guards the secrets of entire generations.

testimonios.testimonio: Every year on the town's anniversary, the children surround the tree to sing to it. They say that when its branches move, it's because it's answering them.

galeriaHistorica.descripcion: Old photograph of the tree in its early years
Old photograph of the tree in its early years

cronologia.descripcion: Planted by the first municipal president
Planning of the local defense during the Revolution
It survived a storm that felled centenary trees

historia.contenido: This 18th-century adobe house sheltered the Martínez family for generations, renowned weavers who preserved pre-Hispanic textile techniques. The walls retain natural pigments used to dye the threads, and the original backstrap loom is still in use.

leyenda.titulo: The loom that sings at night
leyenda.contenido: It is said that on full moon nights, the ancient loom 'sings' with the sound of its threads moving on their own. Neighbors claim it is the spirit of great-grandmother Elena, who swore to keep weaving until her designs were known to the world.

tecnicasTradicionales.descripcion: Pre-Hispanic technique that allows for creating complex designs
Use of the cochineal insect to obtain intense red colors

galeriaHistorica.descripcion: Old photograph of the tree in its early years

cronologia.descripcion: Textiles exhibited at a world's fair
Start of programs to teach techniques to new generations
